column1: Celle (German pronunciation: [ˈtsɛlə]) is a town and capital of the district of Celle
column2: in Lower Saxony
column3: Germany. The town is situated on the banks of the river Aller
column4: a tributary of the Weser and has a population of about 71
column5: 000. Celle is the southern gateway to the Lüneburg Heath
column6: has a castle (Schloss Celle) built in the Renaissance and Baroque style and a picturesque old town centre (the Altstadt) with over 400 timber-framed houses
column7: making Celle one of the most remarkable members of the German Timber-Frame Road. From 1378 to 1705
column8: Celle was the official residence of the Lüneburg branch of the dukes of Brunswick-Lüneburg (House of Welf) who had been banished from their original ducal seat by its townsfolk.

column1: The town of Celle lies in the glacial valley of the Aller
column2: about 40 kilometres (25 mi) northeast of Hanover
column3: 60 kilometres (37 mi) northwest of Brunswick and 120 kilometres (75 mi) south of Hamburg. With 71
column4: 000 inhabitants it is
column6: the largest Lower Saxon town between Hanover and Hamburg.

column1: The town covers an area of 176.05 square kilometres (67.97 sq mi). Flowing from the northeast
column2: the Lachte discharges into the Aller within the town's borders
column3: as does the Fuhse flowing from the southeast. The Aller heads westwards towards Verden an der Aller where it joins the Weser.

column1: Celle's annual precipitation is 692 millimetres (27.2 in) which puts it in the middle third of locations in Germany. 39% of the Deutscher Wetterdienst's weather stations record lower values. The wettest month is August which has 1.5 times the amount of precipitation as February
column2: the driest month. Monthly precipitation varies only slightly and precipitation is very evenly spread throughout the year. Only 1% of German weather stations show a lower annual variation.

column1: The town of Celle has the following 17 boroughs or Stadtteile
column2: some of which were previously independent villages (population as at 1 January 2005): Altencelle (4
column4: Altenhagen (922)

column1: Celle was first mentioned in a document of A.D. 985 as Kiellu (which means Fischbucht or fishing bay). It was granted the right to mint and circulate its own coins (Münzrecht [minting privileges]) during the 11th century and several coins were found in the Sandur hoard in the Faroes. In 1292 Duke Otto II the Strict (1277–1330)
column2: a Welf who ruled the Principality of Lüneburg from 1277 to 1330 left Altencelle
column3: where there had been a defences in the form of a circular rampart (the Ringwall von Burg) since the 10th century
column4: and founded a rectangular settlement by the existing castle (Burg) 4 kilometres (2.5 mi) to the northwest. In 1301 he granted Celle its town privileges
column5: and in 1308 started construction on the town church.

column1: In 1378 Celle became the Residenz of the dukes of Saxe-Wittenberg and
column3: the princes of Lüneburg took up residence in the castle (Schloss). The ducal palace was situated on a triangle between the Aller and its tributary
column4: the Fuhse. A moat connecting the rivers was built in 1433
column5: turning the town centre into an island. In 1452 Duke Frederick the Pious of Lüneburg founded a Franciscan monastery. In 1464 the grain shipping monopoly generated an economic upturn for the town.

column1: In 1524 the Reformation was introduced into Celle. In 1570 Duke William the Younger built the castle chapel which was consecrated in 1585. From 1665 to 1705 Celle experienced a cultural boom as a Residenz under Duke George William. This has been particularly put down to his French wife
column2: Eleonore d'Olbreuse
column3: who brought fellow Huguenot Christians and Italian architects to Celle. During this time the French and Italian Gardens were laid out and the baroque castle theatre built.

column1: In 1705 the last duke of the Brunswick–Lüneburg line died and Celle
column2: along with the Principality of Lüneburg
column3: passed back to the Hanover line of the Welfs. By way of compensation for the loss of its status as a Residenz town numerous administrative institutions were established in Celle
column4: such as the Higher Court of Appeal (Oberappellationsgericht)
column5: the prison and the State Stud Farm. That began its development into an administrative and judicial centre. Even today the Lower Saxony-Bremen State Social Security Tribunal and the High Court responsible for most of Lower Saxony are based in Celle
column6: amongst others. Celle is also still home to a prison (the Justizvollzugsanstalt Celle or JVA Celle). That the citizens of Celle once − in a vote − chose to have a prison in Celle rather than a university in order to protect the virtue of their daughters is not verifiable
column7: but it has remained a persistent anecdote in popular folklore.

column2: George Elector of Hanover
column3: Duke of Brunswick–Lüneburg (King George I) ascended to the British throne. Between then and 1866
column4: when the town became Prussian during the Austro-Prussian War as part of the province of Hanover
column5: Celle was a possession of the British Hanoverian line.

column1: In 1786 Albrecht Thaer founded the first German Agricultural Testing Institute in the meadows at the Dammasch (dam marsh) (today Thaer's Garden). The Albrecht-Thaer School is nowadays part of a vocational centre in the Celle sub-district of Altenhagen.
In 1842 the Cambridge Dragoons Barracks (Cambridge-Dragoner-Kaserne) for the homonymous regiment named after the Hanoveran Viceroy Duke Prince Adolphus
column2: Duke of Cambridge
column3: was built in Celle. After being extended in 1913 and partially rebuilt after a fire in 1936
column4: it was renamed Goodwood Barracks in 1945 and from 1976 to 1996 was the headquarters of Panzerbrigade 33 in the German armed forces
column5: the Bundeswehr. In 1989 it was renamed again to Cambridge-Dragoner-Kaserne. Since 1996 the area has mainly been used to house one of the largest youth centres in Lower Saxony.

column1: From 1869 to 1872 an infantry barracks was built for the 77th Infantry Regiment which also gave the main street (running the length of the front of the barracks) its name of 77er Strasse. In 1938 it was renamed the Heidekaserne ("Heath Barracks"). After the Second World War the barracks was used by British troops until 1993 during which time 94 Locating Regiment Royal Artillery held residency for over 25 years
column2: followed briefly by 14 Signal Regiment
column3: who relocated from Scheuen until the barracks were handed back to the local authorities. Today the New Town Hall (Neue Rathaus) and Celle Council Offices are housed in the restored brick building. Residential buildings and a town park have been established on the rest of the terrain.

column1: In 1892 − with the help of numerous citizens' donations − the present-day Bomann Museum with its important folkloric and town history collections was founded. In 1913 the 74 metre high clock tower was built on the town church
column2: its clockwork underwent a major restoration in 2008. In the 1920s the silk mill was built. It was merged in 1932 with the one in Peine to become the Seidenwerk Spinnhütte AG. This concern expanded itself during the Nazi era into an armaments centre under the name of "Seidenwerk Spinnhütte AG". A subsidiary founded in 1936
column3: the  "Mitteldeutsche Spinnhütte AG"
column4: which led war preparations through its branches in the central German towns of Apolda
column7: Pirna and Wanfried. Its only product was parachute silk that was needed for the paratroopers of the Wehrmacht.In September 1929 Rudolph Karstadt opened a Karstadt department store in Celle town centre
column8: the façade of which was identical with that of the Karstadt store on Berlin's Hermannplatz. The Celle branch was demolished in the 1960s and replaced by a controversial new building
column9: whose aluminium braced facade was meant to represent Celle's timber framed houses.

column2: the anti-Jewish pogrom in Nazi Germany on 9/10 November 1938
column3: the synagogue in Celle was only saved from complete destruction because there would have been a risk to the adjacent leather factory and other parts of the historic Altstadt.

column3: Neuenhäusen
column4: Vorwerk and Wietzenbruch were incorporated into Celle. On 8 April 1945 the only serious allied bombing attack on the city during World War II occurred
column6: especially on the industrial areas and railway freight terminal. A train in which about 4
column7: 000 prisoners were being transported to the nearby Bergen-Belsen concentration camp was hit. The attack claimed hundreds of casualties
column8: but some of the prisoners managed to escape into the nearby woods. SS guards and Celle citizens participated in the so-called 'Celle hare hunt' (Celler Hasenjagd). The 'hunt' claimed several hundred dead and went on until 10 April 1945 and represented the darkest chapter in Celle's history. The exact number of victims has not been determined. Several of the perpetrators were later tried and convicted of this war crime.

column1: About 2.2% of Celle (67 houses) was destroyed in the Second World War. It was spared from further destruction by surrendering without a fight to advancing allied troops on 12 April 1945
column2: so that the historic city centre and the castle survived the war completely unscathed.

Celle was an important garrison location. Elements of the 17th and 73rd Infantry Regiments and the 19th Artillery Regiment were garrisoned in the town. Celle was also the headquarters of a military district command and a military records office.

column1: The different German Army barracks (including the Freiherr von Fritsch Barracks in Scheuen and the Cambridge Dragoons Barracks in the city) were used as sites for the German 33rd Armoured Brigade until the 1990s. The Celle Air Base (Immelmann Barracks) in the District of Wietzenbruch is now the site of the Training Centre of the Army Aviation School and the Cambridge Dragoons Barracks has now become a youth cultural centre (CD-Kaserne).

column2: which as Celle Station formed part of Bergen-Hohne Garrison
column3: were handed over to the German authorities on 5 November 2012. Since German reunification
column4: Celle has largely lost its role as a major garrison town.

column2: along with Bonn and Frankfurt
column3: to become the seat for the Parliamentary Council (Parlamentarischer Rat)
column4: the immediate post-war governmental body in Germany
column5: later superseded by the West German Bundestag. In the end the privilege went to Bonn.

column1: Trenchard Barracks in Celle was the most modern barracks in Germany during the war
column2: with blackout blinds between the double-glazed windows and other features which became commonplace afterwards. The cellar doors were trial rooms for the number of inmates from Belsen who could be gassed.  When Belsen concentration camp was liberated Trenchard Barracks was used as a hospital for surviving inmates who needed treatment. Later it became the Barracks for the 1st Battalion of the Rifle Brigade.

column1: On 1 January 1973 Celle lost its status as an independent town (Kreisfreie Stadt) and became the largest municipality in the new district (Kreis) of Celle. It also became the largest town in the new region (Regierungsbezirk) of Lüneburg. At the same time the localities of Ummern
column2: Pollhöfen and Hahnenhorn were incorporated into Gifhorn district. Since then the parish of Hohne has looked after six villages (Hohne
column3: Helmerkamp
column4: Spechtshorn
column6: Pollhöfen and Hahnenhorn) in two rural districts. The town of Celle has also incorporated a number of villages from the surrounding area.

column1: On 25 July 1978 a staged bomb attack was made on the outer wall of the prison. This was initially blamed on the Red Army Faction
column2: but was later revealed to have been perpetrated by Lower Saxony's intelligence service
column3: the Verfassungsschutz. The incident became known as the Celle Hole.

column1: In 2004 the region of Lüneburg was dissolved along with the rest of Lower Saxony's administrative districts. Celle is currently the twelfth largest town in Lower Saxony.

column1: In the Middle Ages and early modern period Celle only had a few thousand inhabitants. The population grew only slowly and dropped frequently as a result of many wars
column2: epidemics and periods of famine. Not until the beginnings of industrialisation in the 19th century did population growth accelerate. It reached a total of 8
column3: 800 in 1818 but by 1900 this had more than doubled to 20
column4: 000. The incorporation of the surrounding villages on 1 April 1939 saw a further (artificial) rise in numbers to 38

column1: Shortly after the Second World War the many refugees and displaced persons from the German areas of Eastern Europe led to a steep rise in the number of inhabitants within just a few months from around 17
column3: 000 by December 1945. The addition of new municipalities on 1 January 1973 saw an additional 18
column4: 691 people being included within the borough of Celle and bringing the total population to 75

column2: according to an update by the Lower Saxony State Department of Statistics
column3: was 71

column1: For the purposes of Bundestag elections the town of Celle belongs to the constituency of Celle-Uelzen. In 1983
column3: 1990 and 1994 Klaus-Jürgen Hedrich (CDU) won the direct vote. In 1998
column4: 2002 and 2005 Peter Struck (SPD) won the majority of votes. In 2009 Henning Otte (CDU) received the direct mandate.

column1: For Lower Saxony State Parliament (Landtag) elections Celle forms the constituency of Celle-Stadt with its surrounding area. In 2003 the CDU won the majority of votes.
The town council has 42 elected members as well as the directly elected mayor (Oberbürgermeister). Since the local elections of 10 September 2006

column1: The town flag is divided into two equal stripes in the town colours of blue and white. It can also contain the town coat of arms.

The town of Celle has an official seal whose design is based on the oldest town seal of 1288 with the circumscription Stadt Celle. It depicts a gatehouse between two castle towers. In the open gateway under a decorative helmet there is a shield tilting to the left charged with the lion of the Dukes of Lüneburg.
The buildings in Celle's old town centre date back to the 16th century

column3: making Celle an important city for tourism in the southern Lüneburg Heath region. The most impressive building is the ducal palace

column1: The Schlosstheater Celle was founded in 1674 and is the oldest
column2: still working theatre in Germany and the oldest baroque theatre in Europe. It has a main auditorium and two smaller stages (Malersaal and Turmbühne) as well as an additional external venue (Halle 19).

column1: Located at the edge of the old town (Altstadt) is the performing arts theatre Kunst & Bühne which is supported by the town and whose repertoire ranges from comedy to songs

column3: cabaret and films.

column1: The picturesque French Garden lies immediately south of the Altstadt and is where the Lower Saxon Institute of Apiculture may be found. The Castle Park
column2: with its moats
column3: is on the site of the former defensive fortifications of the ducal castle. Along Bahnhofstraße there is an area of common pasture used as a public park and play area (Triftanlagen).

column1: On the right bank of the Aller are the Dammasch Meadows
column2: a popular destination for trips and recreation
column3: and immediately next to them is the garden of medicinal plants and the Thaers Garden with its little manor house. By the New Town Hall (Neues Rathaus) is the recently laid-out town park. Other important open areas include the various town cemeteries
column4: such as the picturesque forest cemetery

column1: The Congress Union Celle is an event centre for conferences and exhibitions as well as stage
column2: music and festive events.

column1: The CD-Kaserne ("Cambridge Dragoons (CD) Barracks") is a municipal youth and cultural centre with exhibition rooms covering the subject areas of music
column2: film
column3: art and society.

column1: Also located there is the Bunte Haus which is a charitable cultural centre. It focuses on projects and events dealing with social questions covering aspects of culture
column2: social work and civic education. Its workers are volunteers.

column1: The Celler Oilers are an ice hockey team that play in the Regionalliga or regional league. From 1968 to the mid-1970s Celle's football club
column2: TuS Celle
column3: played in the German second division (then called the Regionalliga or "regional league"). After two bankruptcies and relegation
column4: it was promoted to the Lower Saxony league for the 2004/2005 season and
column5: since 2005 has played in the Northeast Lower Saxony league (Oberliga Niedersachsen Nordost)
column6: which is fifth tier of the German football league system.

column2: SV Garßen-Celle
column3: has fielded a women's team that had played in the women's Second Division North since the mid-1990s. In 2009 it came first and was promoted to the First Division.

column1: Since 1983 the Celle Wasa Run (Celler Wasa-Lauf) has taken place every year on the second Sunday of March in Celle's town centre. This has become one of the biggest running events in Germany for distances less than a marathon and is divided into runs of several distances: a children's run of 2.5 km (1.6 mi) and runs of 5
column3: 15 and 20 km (12.4 mi) distance. For several years there has also been a hiking (Wandern) event over 11 km (7 mi) along the Aller as well as Walking and Nordic Walking events. 2004 saw a record number of participants with 11
column4: 232 men and women taking part.

column1: Celle is one of five centres for the Lower Saxony Rowing Club. The Celle Sprint Regatta takes place annually in October on the Upper Aller at the Ziegeninsel and is hosted by the Hermann Billung Celle
column2: Celler Ruderverein and Ruderclub Ernestinum-Hölty Celle rowing clubs.

column1: The Celle Triathlon always takes place in August. This was originally organised by the Celle branch of the German Alpine Club (Deutscher Alpenverein)
column2: but for several years has been run by SV Altencelle.

column1: Since 2001 Celle has played host to the In-Line Skating and Handbike Marathon from Hanover to Celle. This is one of the biggest races of its kind in Germany. In 2007 the European Masters speed skating championship took place as part of this event.
Celle also hosted Angola's national football team during the 2006 Football World Cup.
Tourism is a large contributor to Celle's economy
column2: especially in the summer months during jazz
column3: wine
column4: and other festivals

column1: Celle is also known as a town of civil servants
column2: due to the large number of government officials and lawyers who work there providing important administrative and judicial services to the region. Agriculture and forestry also play a role.

column1: Celle is the base for a crispbread factory
column2: Barilla Wasa Deutschland. Regional and to some extent national suppliers are the high-alcohol drink manufactures of the Ratzeputz and Alter Provisor brands. Originally made in Celle's Altstadt
column3: the herb-based spirit Ratzeputz is now distilled on the Westercelle industrial estate
column4: Alter Provisor is still produced and sold in the Altstadt. Celler Bier is also established here with its six varieties of beer. Another Celle speciality is Rohe Roulade
column5: which initially gained fame in the Gasthaus Krohne (now Dackel's Krohne) in the district of Blumlage and is now offered in many of Celle's restaurants and pubs.

column1: The East Hanoverian Railways (Osthannoversche Eisenbahnen or OHE) is a goods and passenger transport company covering the north German area with its headquarters in Celle.
Also based in Celle are the postal distribution centre for Deutsche Post's post code district 29 and the transport company DTLS – Drilling Tools Logistic & Service.

Celle lies on the Hanover – Celle – Uelzen – Lüneburg – Hamburg line. Intercity (IC) trains to Hanover and Hamburg stop hourly at the station as do individual ICE trains during the rush hour. metronom trains link Celle to Uelzen
column2: Hanover and Göttingen as part of the regional transport network. Celle is the terminus for routes S 6 and S 7 of the Hanover S-Bahn.

column1: The section between Celle and Großburgwedel was built in the 1920s as a high-speed line for testing and record journeys across the heath-like
column2: so-called Wietzenbruch. It was nicknamed the Hare Railway (Hasenbahn) due to its environment which was devoid of habitation and the numerous hares killed on the line in its early days. In 1965 this section via Langenhagen was electrified for the TEE and IC services from Hamburg to Hanover
column3: in order to save routing them via Lehrte and having to change direction in Hanover. Later it was upgraded for traffic operating regularly at 200 km/h (124 mph).

column1: Formerly there were railway links from Celle via Schwarmstedt to Bremen (Aller Valley Railway) and via Plockhorst to Brunswick; these were closed in the 1970s and have largely been dismantled. In 2004 the last remaining branch line from Gifhorn to Celle via Wienhausen
column2: that was still used in places for goods traffic
column3: was finally closed and work on lifting the line in the area of the town has begun.

column1: The East Hanoverian Railways run goods trains on several branch lines in the Celle area
column2: including those to Wittingen
column3: Soltau and Munster. Occasionally heritage trains and specials also run on these lines.

column1: The Lehrte–Celle railway is an important route for goods trains and was converted in 1998 into a modern S-Bahn line.
A tramway network of 2 lines had been operated since 1907 by the Celler Straßenbahn but this was closed and dismantled between 1954 and 1956.
North-south: the B 3 running north to Soltau/Hamburg and south to Hanover

column1: Hanover-Langenhagen airport with international flight connections is about 35 kilometres (22 miles) away.
The Army airfield at Celle is 4.5 kilometres southwest of the town centre on the edge of the district of Wietzenbruch. Operated as RAF Celle after the Second World War
column2: it was from here in 1948/49 that supply flights to Berlin took off as part of the Berlin Airlift. Today the airfield is mainly used by the Army Aviation School (Heeresfliegerwaffenschule) as a training airfield for helicopter pilots.

column1: Celle-Arloh airfield near the district of Scheuen is a recreational airfield. It also offers round trips over the town of Celle and the Lüneburg Heath. There is also a glider airfield at Scheuen.

Celle harbour is only used by tourists today. From Celle the Aller is classified downstream as a federal shipping lane; upstream a weir prevents ships passing. In former centuries Celle was an important transhipment station for ships between Brunswick and the ports in Bremen via Oker
column2: Aller and the (Lower) Weser. Bremen and Brunswick merchants had specific tasks from the Dukes of Celle and later the town of Celle in order to ensure the safety of transport
column3: because the speed of the Aller in the area of Celle made loading and unloading in the port necessary.

column1: From 1900 the quantity of trade through Celle Harbour steadily decreased and switched to road and rail. Until 1970 the transport of grain to the Celle Rathsmühle and the transport of potash salts were still significant.
The firm of CeBus runs eight bus lines around the town. There are 15 bus lines for regional services
column2: with which the villages in the district of Celle can be reached. Sometimes town and region bus services are combined.

column1: The Cellesche Zeitung is the local daily newspaper with a circulation of 34
column2: 977 (as at: 2nd quarter 2005). In addition there is the bi-weekly Celler Kurier and weekly Celler Blitz as well as a monthly town magazine
column3: the Celler Scene. Another monthly is the Celler Blickpunkt. The revista appears roughly every 2 months with a left-wing perspective of politics and culture.
